title.narrative: Saving Critical Wintering Habitat for Hudsonian Godwit on Chiloe Island PP

description.narrative: This project will improve roosting and feeding sites for shorebirds and waterbirds in three watersheds identified in the Chiloe Shorebird Conservation Plan; build local conservation constituencies; help establish low-impact tourism; support avoidance and mitigation efforts for key roosting and feeding sites development of proposed wind farms; and develop a capacity-building plan for a local NGO.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will prepare a description of fishing gear used in artisanal fisheries in Chile and its operations; identify areas of greater interaction between these fisheries and leatherbacks; train aritisinal fishers to identify sea turtle species, safe handling and release techniques and data collection on sea turtle bycatch in gillnet operations as described in the proposal.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Support for the 12th Meeting of the Scientific Committee of the InterAmerican Convention for the Protection and Conservation of Sea Turtles (IAC)

description.narrative: The recipeint will organize the 12th meeting of the Scientific Committee for the IAC organize and implement three traing workshops for best practices of safe handling and release of sea turtles accidental caught in net, trawl and long line fisheries.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: SBIRD SITE MAULLIN CHILE

description.narrative: The Maulln wetlands represent one of the largest coastal wetlands in continental Chile and are recognized for their importance as a feeding and resting area for shorebird species of concern, as well as other waterbirds. This project aims to stem the loss and degradation of habitat from unregulated recreational activities (and from the lesser problem of livestock trampling) through the creation of a municipal nature reserve system. The project will also assist the local community to develop birding tourism, which will enhance local support for and appreciation of the reserve network. Benefitted species include snowy plover, lesser yellowlegs, sanderling, hudsonian godwit, whimbrel.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: SECURING SHOREBIRD SITES AT MAULLIN, CHILE

description.narrative: To reduce the loss and degradation of habitat from unregulated recreational activities and livestock disturbance in one of the largest coastal wetlands in continental Chile, the project will: 1) work toward the establishment of a 970-hectare municipal protected area network that provides feeding and resting habitat for Hudsonian Godwit and other shorebirds; 2) develop a management plan for the protected area network; 3) monitor bird numbers and habitat usage, threats, and reserve management outcomes; 4) assist local communities in developing ecotourism and in understanding the importance of the protected areas; 5) create bird observation platforms, signage, radio broadcasts and printed and online information materials.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Stakeholder engagement and training local verifiers of livestock predation: A project to reduce..human-puma conflicts in Chile

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to diminish and prevent livestock predation by pumas in two eco-regions (tropical Andes and temperate forest) of Chile to reduce the justification for their legal or illegal retaliatory killing. Project activities include one set of workshops for local stakeholders in developing and implementing a predation verification system to detect puma predation on livestock and discriminate such events from other causes of livestock loss. A second set of workshops will be directed to livestock owners in selecting, designing and implementing non-lethal interventions based on cost-efficient design, scientific effectiveness, and social acceptability.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: SAVING CRITICAL WINTERING HABITAT FOR TH

description.narrative: Funded under the 2016 IMPACT Program..The marine bays and shorelines of Chilo, located off the coast of Chile, support approximately 22,000 Hudsonian Godwits (nearly 30% of the global population).. However, threats to Hudsonian Godwits and Whimbrels include deforestation of the watersheds by agriculture and livestock and shoreline development, and degradation to the intertidal mud flats principally from algae farming. In order to counter these threats, this project will maintain and enhance wintering populations of Hudsonian Godwit and Whimbrel across a network of sites on Chilo. The project will achieve these goals by increasing sustainable, habitat-conservation focused practices and policies surrounding agriculture and ranching in the area. It will also educate and engage the community on environmental issues to support conservation actions and to maintain long-term ecological viability of five key watersheds on the island. This project will increase the quality and quantity of critical roosting and feeding sites of Hudsonian Godwits and Whimbrels in the Pullao, Putemn and Chullec watersheds. It will establish concessions protecting at least 100 acres of shorebird habitat, plant 3,000 trees, complete agreements with landowners and business on best management practices. It will also engage key stakeholders; strengthen local, low-impact tourism efforts; support the implementation of a land-use management strategy; and support additional planning activities associated with watershed management and renewable energy development. ..Species that will benefit include: red knot, greater yellowlegs, lesser yellowlegs, ruddy turnstone, surfbird, Baird's sandpiper, Wilson's phalarope, Franklin's gull, elegant tern and barn swallow...

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION IN TIERRA DEL FUEGO PROVINCE, CHILE

description.narrative: By creating detailed shorebird habitat maps, this project will set the foundation for conservation planning and action for decades to come at the shorebird wintering site of Baha Lomas in Tierra del Fuego Province, Chile. The proposed area of study is both a RAMSAR site and a Western Hemisphere shorebird site of hemispheric importance. Populations of migratory red knots have declined dramatically in this region in the last 30 years in parallel with declines of similar magnitude in the U.S. in Delaware Bay. The site is also important to other birds such as Red knots, Hudsonian godwits, white-rumped sandpipers, whimbrels and American oystercatchers. This project will delineate critical habitat for five shorebird species in Baha Lomas; map habitats most threatened by climate change, oil pollution, overgrazing and other forms of habitat destruction; and present finding to Chilean biologists and conservation policy specialists.

participating-org.narrative: Conserve Wildlife Foundation of New Jersey

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Living with Pumas in Ultima Esperanza, Chile

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the proposed expansion of an international Biosphere Reserve currently inclusive of Torres del Paine National Park to incorporate approximately 20-25 working ranches in southernmost Chilean Patagonia. This project is intended to conserve Patagonias apex predator, the puma (Puma concolor), and the ecosystem services it provides through testing and implementing methods to reduce puma predation on sheep and engaging local communities to reduce ongoing puma poaching both in and adjacent to Torres del Paine. Activities include: (1) testing the success of guardian dogs in reducing sheep predation within an experimental design; (2) producing robust estimates of puma density in the study area, both in protected Parks and adjacent working ranches; and (3) conducting an educational campaign on sustainable sheep ranching in puma country, safety protocols in ecotourism with pumas as an alternate revenue source to ranching, and the unique importance of the ecological role of pumas in Patagonia.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: PROT & REST SHOREBIRD MIG SITES CHILE S.

description.narrative: Shorebird populations are experiencing large-scale declines along the Pacific Americas Flyway. Wetlands on the ..Pacific coast of Chile provide seasonal foraging and roosting habitats for hundreds of thousands of Neotropical ..migratory shorebirds every year, but they are threatened by development, degradation and pollution. Recently the ..Chilean Government has provided a major opportunity to improve shorebird conservation in Chile through the launch ..of a National Wetlands Protection Initiative. One of the focal sites for the Country's initiative is the Humedal-Marisma ..Rocuant Andalin Important Bird and Biodiversity Area (IBA) in the Concepcin area of central Chile. This site ..supports several Neotropical and Nearctic shorebird Species of Conservation Concern including the Hudsonian ..Godwit and Red Knot. Extensive expertise in conservation planning, saltmarsh restoration, community environmental ..education and development of sustainable economic development tools including bird-based tourism will be mobilized ..to build local capacity that can be replicated in other sites. Major outcomes will include: (1) Development of a ..Conservation Action Plan utilizing the Open Standards methodology and broad community participation, ..(2) Establishment of a community awareness and outreach program, (3) Capacity development for staff from Chilean ..conservation organization CODEFF, local municipalities, and Ministry of Environment personnel.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Restoration of Alejandro Selkirk Island, Chile: Promoting Sustainable land use and livestock production while protecting biodiversity and ecosystem integrity

description.narrative: The Alejandro Selkirk Island is part of the Juan Fernndez Archipelago National Park and a Biosphere Reserve. The island has unparalleled ecosystem diversity and species endemism with 124 species of native plants, over 50% of which are endemic and 35% endangered. Two seabird species, Stejnegers Petrel (Pterodroma longirostris) and Juan Fernndez Petrel (Pterodroma externa), nest only on Alejandro Selkirk Island. The purpose of this project is to curtail unsustainable grazing by free-ranging invasive goats, which threaten critical habitat for native species and endanger ecosystem services for the local fishing communities, thereby serving as a national example of the integration of both human and biodiversity dimensions in protected area management. Specific activities include working collaboratively with local stakeholders to: 1) reduce threats to highly endangered plant and wildlife species through the reduction of the feral goat population on Alejandro Selkirk Island, 2) promote sustainable land use by restricting goat grazing to a multiple-use area, and 3) in collaboration with key agencies and residents, create long-term livestock management plans to ensure lasting protection of critical habitat.

title.narrative: Restoration of Alejandro Selkirk Island, Chile: Promoting Sustainable land use and livestock production while protecting biodiversity and ecosystem integrity

description.narrative: The Alejandro Selkirk Island is part of the Juan Fernndez Archipelago National Park and a Biosphere Reserve. The island has unparalleled ecosystem diversity and species endemism with 124 species of native plants, over 50% of which are endemic and 35% endangered. Two seabird species, Stejnegers Petrel (Pterodroma longirostris) and Juan Fernndez Petrel (Pterodroma externa), nest only on Alejandro Selkirk Island. The purpose of this project is to curtail unsustainable grazing by free-ranging invasive goats, which threaten critical habitat for native species and endanger ecosystem services for the local fishing communities, thereby serving as a national example of the integration of both human and biodiversity dimensions in protected area management. Specific activities include working collaboratively with local stakeholders to: 1) reduce threats to highly endangered plant and wildlife species through the reduction of the feral goat population on Alejandro Selkirk Island, 2) promote sustainable land use by restricting goat grazing to a multiple-use area, and 3) in collaboration with key agencies and residents, create long-term livestock management plans to ensure lasting protection of critical habitat.

title.narrative: CONSERVING PRIORITY SITES FOR SHOREBIRDS

description.narrative: Southern South America supports the majority of the hemispheric and global populations of a large suite of Nearctic migratory shorebirds, including the entire global population of Hudsonian Godwit and large proportions of the populations of rufa Red Knot, the Pacific population of Whimbrel, and White-rumped and Baird's Sandpipers. Many of the key wintering sites for these species in southern South America are facing increasing threats due to significant human-induced changes, and in particular disturbance of roosting and foraging habitat. The Western Hemisphere Reserve Network (WHSRN) Executive Office in collaboration with local partners will enhance conservation of critical shorebird habitats at seven key sites in Chile for priority shorebird species through 1) implementing four new protected areas (covering a total of 9955 ha); 2) catalyzing the protection and/or safeguarding through WHSRN designation of three key sites (covering 2450 ha); 3) building local capacity for effective site conservation at all seven sites; and 4) aligning these local shorebird conservation efforts with national and international plans and initiatives. Project activities will help inform the development of a National Shorebird Conservation Plan, which is being developed within the framework of a national bird conservation strategy, and building from the Pacific Americas Shorebird Conservation Strategy.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: MAINSTREAMING COASTAL BIRD CONSERVATION

description.narrative: Wetlands on the Pacific coast of Chile provide critical habitats for hundreds of thousands of Neotropical migratory shorebirds and marine birds every year, but are threatened by unsustainable development, degradation, and pollution. The Chilean Ministry of Environment has created major opportunities to improve Neotropical migratory bird conservation in the country through the launch of a new National Wetlands Protection Plan and a Global Environmental Facility (GEF)-6 project on the conservation and adaptive management of coastal wetlands. Combined, these initiatives represent the best opportunity in decades to work with the Chilean Government and local conservation organizations to fully integrate bird conservation into national conservation and development agendas. This proposal has the following goals, focusing on both national and local, on-the-ground action in Chile's South Center Biodiversity Hotspot: 1) birds are mainstreamed into national policy and economic development agendas through implementation of the Chilean Bird Conservation Strategy; 2) the economic value of migratory and resident birds and their habitats are strengthened by building bird-based tourism capacities across the Central Chile Coastal birding trail; and 3) a community engagement and stewardship program is developed and implemented at the Humedal-Marisma Rocuant Andalin IBA to reduce human disturbances to migratory shore and coastal marine birds.

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE HUEMUL AND THE BASE OF THE TOWERS: MITIGATING TOURISM & LIVESTOCK INDUCED HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT IN TORRES DEL PAINE

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT IN TORRES DEL PAINE NATIONAL PARK IN CHILEAN PATAGONIA RELATED TO THE ENDANGERED HUEMUL. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE HUEMUL CONSERVATION BY MITIGATING THREATS POSED BY PRIVATELY OWNED LIVESTOCK AND TOURISM TO THE HUMAN WILDLIFE CONFLICT. THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE THE ENDANGERED SOUTH ANDEAN DEER (HIPPOCAMELUS BISULCUS), OR HUEMUL, AND ITS BIODIVERSE HABITATS BY ADDRESSING PUBLIC PRIVATE CONFLICT, DRASTICALLY REDUCING RISK OF DISEASE TRANSMISSION IN THE NATIONAL PARK, AND IMPROVING UNSUSTAINABLE VISITOR MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE REALIGNING THE PUBLIC PORTION OF THE BASE OF THE TOWERS TRAIL FOR SAFER, LESS INVASIVE, SUSTAINABLE DESIGN CONFLICT RESOLUTION WITH PRIVATE LAND OWNERS WHOSE DOMESTIC ANIMALS THREATEN HUEMUL HABITATS IN TORRES DEL PAINE PARTICIPATIVE WORKSHOPS WITH THE LOCAL COMMUNITY TO IMPROVE AWARENESS, EDUCATION, AND GARNER COMMITMENT TO LONG TERM CONSERVATION ACTIONS REMOVAL OF LIVESTOCK FROM THE NATIONAL PARK AND INSTALLATION OF A 4KM, WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FENCE BETWEEN THE NATIONAL PARK AND PRIVATE ESTANCIAS TO PREVENT LIVESTOCK FROM RE ENTERING COLLECTIVE MONITORING OF HUEMUL HABITATS FOR REPOPULATION, DAMAGE TO FENCE, AND PRESENCE OF LIVESTOCK WITH PARK RANGERS, GUIDES, AND PRIVATE LAND OWNERS PA
